newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds drift lower, await Greenspan.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds drift lower, await Greenspan.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities fell in line with Treasuries on Tuesday, but pass-through yield spreads narrowed slightly, traders said.

Retail buying in pass-throughs is expected to keep spreads tighter as the market braces for the second leg of Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony Wednesday, they said.
"Mortgage (prices) are going down with Treasuries, and Treasuries are going down because of fear of what (Greenspan) is going to say," one trader said.
"Anytime the (Treasury) market trades off, we'll be in doing some buying," he said, adding that his firm had bought mortgage paper in a wide range of maturities.
By late afternoon, mortgages had slipped 1/32 to 7/32 overall, while comparable Treasuries were down 5/32 to 7/32.

In key coupons, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5-percent paper had fallen 5/32, yielding 105 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note. Comparable Fannie Mae paper was 5/32 lower at 99-18/32, and Freddie Mac issues were off 6/32 at 99-23/32.
The 10-year Treasury note was off 7/32 at 97-15/32 to yield 6.60 percent.
